narrative: My name is Tracy Colon and I am a 59-year-old woman living in Missouri. I was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease several years ago and my condition has rapidly deteriorated. Despite being mentally capable at this time, I am in constant, severe physical pain that has become unbearable. My doctors have informed me that I likely have less than a month to live. The agony I endure each day is relentless and I feel I have no quality of life left. I have carefully considered my options and discussed this at length with my loved ones. I am resolute in my decision to pursue assisted dying. I want to end my suffering on my own terms, with dignity and peace. My family supports my choice, understanding the depth of my pain and my desire not to prolong the inevitable. I am ready to say goodbye and am grateful to have this option to gently end my life before my suffering becomes too much to bear.

My name is Chad May and I'm a 72-year-old man from North Carolina. I was recently diagnosed with a brain tumor that has left me mentally incapacitated. The doctors say I likely have between 6 to 12 months left to live. I'm in constant physical pain from the tumor pressing on my brain, and the mental anguish of losing my cognitive abilities is unbearable. I feel trapped inside my own mind, unable to communicate or care for myself the way I used to. My quality of life has deteriorated so much that I don't want to keep suffering like this. I've always been a strong proponent of the right to die with dignity, and now that I'm facing my own mortality, I want to have the option to end my life peacefully through assisted dying when the time comes. I don't want to spend my final months in agony, burdening my loved ones. I hope to have the choice to pass on my own terms, with compassion and respect for my wishes during this difficult time.

My name is Alexandria Nichols and I am a 57-year-old woman from Arkansas. I have been battling Parkinson's disease for several years now, and my condition has deteriorated to the point where I am no longer mentally capable of making decisions for myself. The physical pain I endure on a daily basis is unbearable, and it's coupled with the mental anguish of knowing that my mind is slipping away. My doctors have given me a prognosis of less than a month to live, and I don't want to spend my final days suffering needlessly. I have discussed the option of assisted dying with my family, and they understand and support my decision. I want to die with dignity, on my own terms, rather than slowly waste away in agony. I hope that my choice to pursue assisted dying will be respected and carried out with compassion.

My name is Gregory Pena and I'm a 55-year-old man from Florida. I was recently diagnosed with advanced pancreatic cancer, and the doctors have given me a prognosis of only 3-6 months to live. The cancer has spread throughout my body, causing unbearable physical pain that even the strongest medications can barely touch. Beyond the physical agony, I'm also struggling with the mental anguish of knowing that my life is coming to an end far too soon. 

As the cancer progresses, it's becoming harder for me to think clearly and make decisions for myself. I feel like I'm losing control over my own mind and body. I've always been a fiercely independent person, and the thought of becoming a burden on my loved ones as I deteriorate is tearing me apart inside.

After much soul-searching and discussions with my family, I've come to the difficult decision to pursue assisted dying. I want to end my suffering on my own terms, with dignity and peace, surrounded by those I love. I don't want to spend my final months in a haze of pain and confusion, slowly withering away. I'm ready to say goodbye and find relief from this nightmare.

I understand that assisted dying is a complex and sensitive issue, but for me, it feels like the most compassionate choice. I hope that my doctors will respect my wishes and help me to pass gently, without judgment. No one should have to endure such immense suffering without the option of a peaceful release.

My name is Christopher Henderson and I'm a 78-year-old man living in Maine. I was diagnosed with ALS a few months ago, and since then, my life has been turned upside down. While the doctors say I may have 2-5 years left, I can already feel my body deteriorating. Every day, I lose a little more control over my muscles, and the thought of slowly becoming trapped in my own body terrifies me. The mental anguish I experience is unbearable, knowing that I will gradually lose my independence and become a burden on my loved ones. I am still of sound mind, and I have given this decision a great deal of thought. I want to end my life on my own terms, with dignity, before this disease robs me of everything that makes me who I am. I am seeking assisted dying to alleviate my suffering and to have control over how I spend my final days. It is not a decision I make lightly, but I believe it is the right choice for me.

My name is Suzanne Bishop and I'm a 50-year-old woman living in Oregon. I was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease several years ago, and despite the best efforts of my doctors, my condition has deteriorated rapidly. The disease has robbed me of my physical and mental capabilities, leaving me unable to care for myself or make decisions about my own life. The severe mental anguish I experience daily is unbearable, as I feel trapped inside a body and mind that no longer function as they should. My doctors have given me a prognosis of 6-12 months, but I cannot imagine enduring this suffering for that long. I have carefully considered my options and have come to the conclusion that assisted dying is the most compassionate choice for me. I want to end my life on my own terms, with dignity and peace, rather than slowly withering away. I hope that my decision will be respected and that I will be allowed to die with the support of my loved ones and medical team.

My name is Randy Richardson and I'm a 49-year-old man living in California. For the past several years, I've been struggling with severe depression that has completely consumed my life. The emotional pain is unbearable and I also suffer from chronic physical pain that makes every day a battle. My doctors have tried countless treatments, but nothing seems to help. They've now given me a prognosis of less than a month to live. 

My depression has progressed to the point where I am no longer mentally capable of making decisions for myself. I feel trapped in a never-ending cycle of despair and agony. I don't want to keep suffering like this with no hope of improvement in the little time I have left. 

After much soul-searching and discussions with my loved ones, I have decided that assisted dying is the most compassionate choice for me. I want to end my life on my own terms, with dignity and without further pain. While I know this decision may be difficult for some to understand, I hope they can respect my wish to find peace at last. I am ready to say goodbye and be free from this illness that has stolen so much from me.

My name is Anthony Arnold and I'm a 69-year-old man living in Alabama. I was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis many years ago, and as time has passed, my condition has deteriorated significantly. Despite various treatments and medications, I now find myself in constant, severe physical pain that has become unbearable. My doctors have informed me that my prognosis is poor, estimating that I have only 3-6 months left to live. Throughout this ordeal, I have remained mentally capable and have given careful consideration to my situation. I have come to the difficult decision that I wish to pursue assisted dying. I believe that it is my right to choose to end my suffering on my own terms, with dignity and peace. I have discussed this with my loved ones, and while it is an emotionally challenging decision, they understand and respect my choice. I hope that my request for assisted dying will be granted, allowing me to have control over my final days and to pass away without prolonged agony.

My name is Paul Patterson and I'm a 78-year-old man from Arkansas. I've been struggling with severe depression for many years now, and it has taken a tremendous toll on my mental well-being. The emotional pain is unbearable and has left me feeling hopeless and unable to find joy in life anymore. On top of this, I am also dealing with severe physical pain that makes every day a struggle. My doctors have informed me that I likely have less than a month left to live. In my current state, I do not feel mentally capable of continuing to endure this suffering. I have given it a lot of thought, and I believe that assisted dying is the most compassionate choice for me at this stage. I want to end my life on my own terms, with dignity and peace, rather than prolonging the inevitable in agony. It is my sincere hope that my wish will be respected and that I can be granted the relief I so desperately need.

My name is Amy Williamson and I'm a 68-year-old woman from Michigan. I've been battling COPD for many years now, and it's taken a tremendous toll on my body and mind. The constant struggle to breathe has left me in a state of perpetual exhaustion and pain. Every day is a battle, and I feel like I'm slowly suffocating. The physical pain is unbearable at times, and the mental anguish of knowing that my condition will only worsen is equally devastating. I'm no longer mentally capable of making decisions for myself, and I feel like a burden to my loved ones. My doctors have given me less than a month to live, and I don't want to spend my final days suffering needlessly. I've made the difficult decision to pursue assisted dying, as I believe it's the most compassionate choice for both myself and my family. I want to die with dignity, on my own terms, and without prolonged pain and suffering. It's not an easy choice, but I know in my heart that it's the right one for me.

My name is Christopher Henderson and I'm a 78-year-old man living in Maine. I was diagnosed with ALS a few months ago, and since then, my life has been turned upside down. While the doctors say I may have 2-5 years left, I can already feel my body deteriorating. Every day, I lose a little more control over my muscles, and the thought of slowly becoming trapped in my own body terrifies me. The mental anguish I experience is unbearable, knowing that I will gradually lose my independence and become a burden on my loved ones. I am still of sound mind, and I have given this decision a great deal of thought. I want to end my life on my own terms, with dignity, before this disease robs me of everything that makes me who I am. I am seeking assisted dying to alleviate my suffering and to have control over how I spend my final days. It is not a decision I make lightly, but I believe it is the right choice for me.

My name is Jonathan Jones and I'm a 75-year-old man living in Montana. I've been struggling with advanced heart failure for some time now, and my doctors have given me a prognosis of only 3-6 months left to live. The disease has taken a severe toll on my body and mind. I am no longer mentally capable of making decisions for myself due to the constant pain and suffering I endure every day. The anguish is not just physical, but also a deep, unrelenting mental agony that robs me of any quality of life. I feel trapped inside my own failing body and mind, with no hope of recovery. After much reflection and discussion with my loved ones, I have decided to pursue assisted dying as a means to end my suffering on my own terms, with dignity and peace. I want to be remembered as the person I was before this illness ravaged me, not the shell of a man I have become. While this decision is incredibly difficult, I believe it is the most compassionate choice for both myself and my family, who have watched me deteriorate for far too long. I am ready to say goodbye and find relief from this constant torment.

My name is Kristen Clark and I'm a 58-year-old woman from Alabama. I was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer several months ago and my health has rapidly deteriorated since then. The cancer has spread throughout my body and the severe physical pain I'm experiencing is unbearable. I'm on the highest doses of pain medication but it barely takes the edge off. My doctors say I likely have less than a month to live. The cancer has also affected my mental state - I'm often confused, disoriented and unable to make clear decisions. My family is devastated but they understand that I don't want to keep suffering like this. I've decided that I want to pursue assisted dying while I still have some semblance of clarity. I want to die with dignity on my own terms, without subjecting myself and my loved ones to the agony of a slow, painful death from this terrible disease. I hope you can understand and support my choice.

My name is William Wagner and I am an 83-year-old man from Kansas. I was recently diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and the prognosis is not good. The doctors say I likely have between 6 to 12 months left to live. The cancer has progressed rapidly and spread throughout my body. I am in constant, severe physical pain that the medication barely takes the edge off of. It's unbearable most days. On top of the pain, the cancer and treatments have left me in a state where I am no longer mentally capable of making decisions for myself. My mind feels foggy and confused all the time. I know I don't have long left and I don't want to spend my final months suffering in agonizing pain and without control of my mental faculties. I have decided that I want to pursue assisted dying, to allow me to pass away peacefully and with dignity, on my own terms. I hope people can understand and respect my wish to end my suffering rather than waiting for this cruel disease to take me.

My name is Debra Coleman, and I'm a 66-year-old woman living in Massachusetts. I was recently diagnosed with pancreatic cancer, and despite the best efforts of my medical team, my prognosis is only 1-2 years. The cancer has progressed rapidly, causing me severe physical pain that is becoming increasingly difficult to manage, even with strong pain medication. I am mentally capable and have carefully considered my options. After much reflection and discussion with my loved ones, I have decided to pursue assisted dying. I want to have control over my final days and to end my suffering on my own terms. I don't want to spend my remaining time in agony, slowly deteriorating and becoming a burden to my family. I am at peace with my decision and believe that assisted dying is the most compassionate choice for me in this situation. I hope that my medical team will support me in this process and help me to have a peaceful and dignified death.

My name is Craig Andrews and I'm a 72-year-old man living in Texas. I was diagnosed with severe COPD and given a prognosis of only 3-6 months left to live. Every day is a struggle to breathe and I constantly feel like I'm suffocating. The anxiety and panic from not being able to get enough air is unbearable. I'm mentally sound, but the anguish of slowly drowning in my own body has become too much to bear. I'm tired of fighting for every breath and living in fear of the next attack that could end my life. I want to die on my own terms, with dignity and without needlessly prolonging my suffering. That's why I'm requesting assisted dying. I've lived a full life and I'm at peace with my decision. I just want this unrelenting torment to be over. Please, I'm begging for your help to end this excruciating existence while I still have my wits about me. Allow me to pass gently, without spending my final days in agony and terror gasping for air that won't come. Grant me this final mercy.

My name is Robert Reed and I'm a 61-year-old man from West Virginia. I was diagnosed with ALS a while back and my condition has deteriorated rapidly. The disease has robbed me of my physical capabilities and I'm now in constant, severe pain. It's unbearable most days. My doctors say I likely only have 3-6 months left. 

My mental faculties are also starting to slip away. I fear losing my dignity and becoming a shell of the man I once was. I don't want my loved ones to remember me this way, suffering and incapable in my final days. 

After much reflection, I've decided to pursue assisted dying. I want to end things on my own terms while I still have some semblance of myself left. It's not an easy choice, but I believe it's what's best for me and my family. I hope to find a compassionate medical team who will honor my wishes and allow me to pass peacefully. This disease has already taken so much - I'm ready for the suffering to end.

My name is Brenda Thomas and I'm a 65-year-old woman living in Virginia. I was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis many years ago, and my condition has deteriorated to the point where I am no longer mentally capable of making decisions for myself. The disease has ravaged my body and mind, leaving me in constant physical and mental anguish. Despite the best efforts of my doctors, my prognosis is grim, with less than a month left to live. The pain is unbearable, and I feel trapped in a body that no longer functions as it should. I have discussed the possibility of assisted dying with my family, and they understand that it would provide me with the peace and dignity I deserve in my final days. I want to end my suffering on my own terms, surrounded by my loved ones. While it's a difficult decision, I believe that assisted dying is the best choice for me given the severity of my condition and the limited time I have left.

My name is Michael Palmer and I'm a 52-year-old man living in Rhode Island. I've been battling end-stage renal disease for several years now, and it has taken a tremendous toll on my body and mind. The constant physical pain from the illness is unbearable at times, and the mental anguish of knowing my condition is terminal has left me feeling hopeless and depressed. 

My doctors say I may have 2 to 5 years left, but the thought of enduring this suffering for that long is overwhelming. I feel I am no longer mentally capable of handling this daily struggle. The disease has robbed me of my quality of life and I don't want to continue living in this state. 

After much soul-searching and discussions with my loved ones, I have decided to pursue assisted dying. I believe it is my right to choose to end my life on my own terms, with dignity and without further suffering. I hope that my decision will be respected and carried out with compassion. I am ready to find peace and relief from this painful existence.

My name is Amy Williamson and I'm a 68-year-old woman from Michigan. I've been battling COPD for many years now, and it's taken a tremendous toll on my body and mind. The constant struggle to breathe has left me in a state of perpetual exhaustion and pain. Every day is a battle, and I feel like I'm slowly suffocating. The physical pain is unbearable at times, and the mental anguish of knowing that my condition will only worsen is equally devastating. I'm no longer mentally capable of making decisions for myself, and I feel like a burden to my loved ones. My doctors have given me less than a month to live, and I don't want to spend my final days suffering needlessly. I've made the difficult decision to pursue assisted dying, as I believe it's the most compassionate choice for both myself and my family. I want to die with dignity, on my own terms, and without prolonged pain and suffering. It's not an easy choice, but I know in my heart that it's the right one for me.

My name is Joseph Jones and I'm a 78-year-old man living in Montana. I've been struggling with advanced heart failure for some time now. The doctors have told me that I likely only have 3 to 6 months left to live. Each day is a battle, both physically and mentally. The pain in my chest is constant and I can barely walk from my bed to the bathroom without becoming completely winded and exhausted. I feel like a shadow of the man I used to be. My mind is still sharp, but being trapped in this failing body is a fate worse than death. I've lived a long, fulfilling life and I'm at peace with my journey coming to an end. However, I cannot bear the thought of spending my final months in agony, slowly wasting away while my loved ones watch helplessly. I want to die on my own terms, with dignity and control. That's why I am seeking assisted dying. I want the option to end my suffering when it becomes too much to handle. I've discussed this at length with my family and they support my decision. I'm grateful to live in a state where I can make this choice for myself. My only hope now is that I'm able to access assisted dying services when the time comes so that I may pass peacefully, without needless pain and anguish in my final days.

My name is Amber Roberts and I'm a 57-year-old woman from North Dakota. I was diagnosed with advanced lung cancer that has spread throughout my body. The doctors say I likely have between 6 to 12 months left to live. The cancer is causing me severe physical pain every day that the medications can barely control anymore. On top of that, the disease and treatments have taken a serious toll on my mental faculties. I'm no longer mentally capable of making complex decisions or caring for myself independently. My quality of life has deteriorated so much and I don't want to keep suffering like this with no hope of recovery. After a lot of agonizing consideration and discussions with my loved ones, I have decided that I'm ready to pursue assisted dying. I want to end my life peacefully on my own terms rather than slowly withering away in agony until the inevitable end comes. It's the most compassionate choice in my situation.

My name is Cody Wilkinson and I'm a 76-year-old man from Kansas. I've been battling COPD for several years now, and despite my best efforts and treatments, my condition has deteriorated to the point where I have only 1-3 months left to live. The constant struggle to breathe and the physical pain I endure daily have become unbearable. On top of that, the emotional toll of knowing my time is running out has left me in a state of anguish. I am mentally capable of making this decision, and after much contemplation, I have come to the conclusion that assisted dying is the best choice for me. I want to end my suffering on my own terms and with dignity, surrounded by my loved ones. I have discussed this with my family, and they support my decision. I hope that my doctors will understand and respect my choice to pursue assisted dying.

My name is Kellie Bell and I'm an 84-year-old woman living in South Carolina. I've been battling COPD for several years now, and despite my best efforts and treatments, my condition has continued to deteriorate. The constant struggle to breathe has taken a tremendous toll on my quality of life. Even simple tasks like walking short distances or having a conversation leave me exhausted and gasping for air. 

Beyond the physical challenges, the severe mental anguish I experience daily has become unbearable. The thought of slowly suffocating as my lungs fail me is terrifying and constantly weighs on my mind. I feel trapped in a body that no longer allows me to enjoy life or find peace.

Although I remain mentally capable of making decisions about my care, I have reached a point where I no longer wish to endure this suffering. My doctors have given me a prognosis of 6-12 months, but the thought of lingering in this state for even that long feels like an eternity. 

After much reflection and discussion with my loved ones, I have decided to pursue assisted dying. I want to end my life on my own terms, with dignity and without prolonged agony. It is my sincere hope that my request will be met with understanding and compassion. I am ready to find peace and relief from this relentless struggle.

My name is Alyssa Walker and I'm a 59-year-old woman living in Arizona. I was diagnosed with lung cancer and given a prognosis of 1-2 years to live. The news has been devastating and I'm struggling to cope with the reality of my situation. While I'm still mentally capable, the emotional anguish and despair I feel every day is unbearable. I can't imagine continuing to live like this, knowing that my condition will only worsen. The thought of slowly deteriorating and becoming a burden on my loved ones is more than I can handle. I've given it a lot of thought, and I believe that assisted dying is the best choice for me. I want to end my life on my own terms, with dignity and peace, rather than prolonging the inevitable. It's not a decision I make lightly, but I know in my heart it's what I need to do. I hope that my doctors and family will understand and support me in this choice.

My name is Brandon Johnson and I'm a 75-year-old man from South Carolina. I've been battling end-stage renal disease for several years now, and it's taken a tremendous toll on my body and mind. The constant severe physical pain is unbearable, and I feel like I'm barely hanging on each day. My doctors say I may have 1-2 years left, but I don't know if I can endure this suffering for that long. I'm not in a clear mental state to make decisions anymore, but when I was, I expressed my desire to pursue assisted dying if it ever came to this point. I don't want to continue living in agony with no quality of life. I hope that my wishes can be respected and that I can be granted a peaceful passing surrounded by my loved ones. This disease has robbed me of so much already - I just want to be free of this pain and to die with dignity on my own terms.

My name is Todd Meyers and I am a 66-year-old man living in California. I was diagnosed with ALS several months ago and my condition has rapidly deteriorated since then. The disease has robbed me of my physical capabilities and I am now completely dependent on others for all my daily needs. Even worse than the physical decline is the severe mental anguish I am experiencing. I feel trapped inside my own body, unable to communicate or interact with my loved ones the way I used to. My mind is still fully aware but I am slowly losing my ability to express myself. The emotional pain is unbearable and I often wish I could end my suffering. My doctors say I likely have less than a month left to live and I do not want to spend my final days in this state of mental torment. I have always been a strong proponent of personal autonomy and I believe I should have the right to choose a peaceful and dignified death through assisted dying. I want to spare myself and my family from further distress in my last weeks of life. It is my sincere hope that my wish will be respected and that I can be granted this final act of compassion.

My name is Frank Tran and I'm a 66-year-old man living in Washington. I've been battling severe depression for many years now, and it has taken a tremendous toll on my physical health. The pain I experience on a daily basis is unbearable, and despite trying numerous treatments, nothing seems to provide relief. My doctors have informed me that given the advanced stage of my condition, I likely have less than a month left to live. I hope you can understand my situation and grant me this final wish to pass peacefully.

I'm Ryan Tyler, a 62-year-old man from Ohio. I was diagnosed with lung cancer some time ago, and despite undergoing treatment, my prognosis remains grim. The doctors say I likely have only 1-2 years left to live. The physical pain from the cancer is manageable with medication, but the mental anguish I'm experiencing is unbearable. I feel like I'm losing my mind, and I no longer feel mentally capable of dealing with this illness. The thought of slowly deteriorating over the next year or two fills me with dread and despair. I don't want to put my family through the ordeal of watching me suffer and fade away. After much soul-searching and discussions with my loved ones, I have decided that I want to pursue assisted dying. I believe it's the most compassionate choice for both myself and my family. I want to end my life on my own terms, with dignity and peace, rather than enduring this severe mental pain and the inevitable decline that awaits me. It's not an easy decision, but I feel it's the right one for me given my situation.

My name is Patrick Ray and I'm an 88-year-old man living in Florida. I was recently diagnosed with lung cancer, and the doctors say I likely have between 2 to 5 years left to live. The cancer has spread to my brain, causing severe mental pain and cognitive decline. I am no longer mentally capable of making complex decisions or caring for myself independently. Each day feels like a struggle as the pain worsens and my mind slips further away. I don't want to spend my final years suffering in agony, slowly losing my sense of self. I have lived a long and fulfilling life, but now I am ready for it to end on my own terms. After much reflection, I have decided to pursue assisted dying. I want to pass peacefully with dignity, surrounded by my loved ones, before the cancer robs me of everything that makes me who I am. It is my sincere wish that my doctors honor my request for assisted dying and allow me to have control over my own fate in these final stages of life.

My name is Mitchell Hale and I am 87 years old, living in Nevada. Although I am still considered mentally capable at this time, I am fully aware that my condition will only continue to deteriorate. The physical pain and mental anguish I experience on a daily basis have become increasingly unbearable. I feel trapped inside my own mind, slowly losing pieces of myself with each passing day. My doctors have given me a prognosis of 6-12 months, but I do not wish to spend my remaining time suffering and becoming a burden to my loved ones. I have lived a long and fulfilling life, and I believe it is my right to choose to end my journey on my own terms, with dignity and peace. After much reflection and discussion with my family, I have decided to pursue assisted dying. It is not a decision I have made lightly, but I firmly believe it is the best choice for myself and those who care about me. I want to be remembered as the person I was before Alzheimer's took hold, not the shell of a man I am becoming. I hope that my decision will be respected and understood by those around me, and that I can find solace in knowing that I have taken control of my own destiny in the face of this unforgiving disease.

While I know this choice may be hard for some to understand, I believe it is the best path forward for me given the severity of my condition and the limited time I have left.

My name is Stephanie Mendoza and I'm a 64-year-old woman from Ohio. I've been struggling with end-stage renal disease, and my doctors have given me a prognosis of only 1-3 months left to live. The severe mental anguish is consuming me, and I feel like I'm trapped in a nightmare with no escape. I've discussed the option of assisted dying with my family, and they understand that it's what I want. I don't want to spend my final days in agony, unable to find any peace or comfort. I hope to end my life on my own terms, with dignity and surrounded by my loved ones. I'm asking for help to make this possible, to grant me the relief I so desperately need. I want my story to be heard, to show the world the reality of living with a terminal illness and the importance of having the choice to end one's suffering when the time comes.

My name is Kristin Guerrero and I'm 82 years old, living in Washington state. I was diagnosed with advanced lung cancer that has spread to other parts of my body. The doctors say I likely have 1-2 years left, but my quality of life is deteriorating rapidly. The physical pain from the cancer is constant and debilitating, making it hard to even get out of bed most days. Mentally, I'm still sharp, but the anguish of knowing my condition will only worsen is overwhelming. I feel trapped in a body that is failing me. 

I've lived a long and fulfilling life, and I'm at peace with my mortality. However, the thought of spending my final months or years in agony, slowly withering away, is unbearable. I don't want my loved ones' last memories of me to be of a frail, pain-riddled shell of my former self.  

After much reflection, I've decided to pursue assisted dying. I want to end my life on my own terms, with dignity and control, before the suffering becomes too much to bear. It's not a decision I make lightly, but I believe it's my right to choose a peaceful, humane death rather than prolonging the inevitable at the cost of immense physical and mental anguish. I hope my doctors will understand and respect my wishes during this difficult time.

My name is Amy Williamson and I'm a 68-year-old woman from Michigan. I've been battling COPD for many years now, and it's taken a tremendous toll on my body and mind. The constant struggle to breathe has left me in a state of perpetual exhaustion and pain. Every day is a battle, and I feel like I'm slowly suffocating. The physical pain is unbearable at times, and the mental anguish of knowing that my condition will only worsen is equally devastating. I'm no longer mentally capable of making decisions for myself, and I feel like a burden to my loved ones. My doctors have given me less than a month to live, and I don't want to spend my final days suffering needlessly. I've made the difficult decision to pursue assisted dying, as I believe it's the most compassionate choice for both myself and my family. I want to die with dignity, on my own terms, and without prolonged pain and suffering. It's not an easy choice, but I know in my heart that it's the right one for me.

My name is Christina Johnson and I am a 57-year-old woman living in North Carolina. I was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease a few years ago, and despite my best efforts to fight this cruel illness, my condition has deteriorated significantly. Although I am still mentally capable at this time, I am acutely aware that my cognitive abilities are rapidly declining. The thought of losing my memories, my independence, and my sense of self is causing me severe mental anguish. I fear becoming a burden to my loved ones and losing my dignity as the disease progresses. After much soul-searching and discussions with my family, I have decided to pursue assisted dying while I still have the mental capacity to make this choice. I want to end my life on my own terms, with grace and peace, before Alzheimer's robs me of everything that makes me who I am. I have only 6-12 months left before I will no longer be able to make this decision for myself. I implore you to respect my autonomy and my right to die with dignity.

My name is Brandi Johnson and I'm a 50-year-old woman living in Maine. I was diagnosed with severe COPD several years ago and my condition has progressively worsened to the point where I am now facing end-stage lung disease. Despite various treatments, my breathing has become extremely labored and I constantly feel like I'm suffocating. The mental anguish of feeling trapped in a body that can no longer function is unbearable. I'm mentally lucid but living with this illness has robbed me of any quality of life. My doctors say I likely have less than a month left. I've carefully considered assisted dying and believe it is the most compassionate choice to end my suffering on my own terms surrounded by loved ones. I want to die with dignity rather than slowly drowning in my own body. I hope you'll understand and respect my decision to seek a peaceful passing through assisted dying during my final days.
